Through this support, NADMO completed the testing of an effective flood and drought Early Warning system at the NADMO HQ, 10 Regional Offices and in 10 districts across the Country. The Community Resilience through Early Warning system (CREW EWS) uses open free of charge satellite based meteorological data and provides a basic flood and drought forecast for all the pilot areas. The CREW EWS exists of two systems: an expert system that collects data, calculates forecasts and presents all relevant data and a web dissemination tool called “Dashboard” that visualizes specific warnings and flood hazard information through a dedicated website. With the aid of these systems, the skill in estimates of the intensity of rainfall is expected to improve to provide reasonably accurate rainfall forecasts to issue early warning. Institutions like the National Disaster Management Organization (NADMO) and the pilot districts need warning information about abnormally high or untimely rainfall to enable them to mobilize in advance. In the coming years, it is expected that the EWS will help make contingency planning and evacuation more precise and therefore, put people and potentially economic/livelihood assets out of the harm’s way. A good understanding of the types of hazards and their risks that Ghana as a country face, as well as the characteristics of hazards that local governments, communities, and individuals must plan and prepare for, are essential components to enhance DRR. 1. The project provided technical support to review the existing policy and guideline on Health Care Waste Management (HCWM) - the final drafts are undergoing their final review and will be available in early 2018. The Hazardous Waste Act 2016 was reviewed to ensure that health care waste management concerns are incorporated. The Standards of Operations Procedures (SOPs) on HCWM for teaching and regional hospitals and health centers have been finalized and are being piloted in the five pilot facilities. The project is therefore providing a substantive contribution to strengthen institutional capacities to enhance HCWM related policies and regulatory frameworks.
2. . The project has forged a partnership between Ghana Health Service and three Schools of Hygiene (Accra, Ho and Tamale) to review the current educational curriculum on HCWM for the award of a degree in these institutions. The curriculum will be administered from the 2017/2018 academic year. This is an important achievement as it institutionalizes HCWM as a topic in this type of schools that train health care workers operating across the country.
3. The 5 pilot health facilities have also acquired deep knowledge of best environmental practices in HCWM, through intensive training of about 300 health care workers (60% women) from all categories of staff (clinical and non-clinical).
4. A total of 443 Mercury free devices (225 thermometers and 218 sphygmomanometers) have been supplied p to selected units in 2 teaching hospitals, 2 regional hospitals and 1 health centre. This replacement exercise sets the tone for Ghana to gradually phase out mercury use in the health sector as required by the Minamata Convention on Mercury. Health staff were also given training on the use and management of these equipment. 1) National inception was organised in February 2017 2) A national steering committee has been constituted and have met 2 times in the year to monitor implementation progress and make suggestions fir future activities 3) 7 public officers from EPA, Ghana Atomic Energy Commission and the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology were trained on how to carry out national mercury inventories according to UN standards. 4) This enabled them and their teams to conduct a nation-wide survey to collect data and develop a preliminary inventory on Ghana’s mercury use and sources.
